newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - July 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - July 23.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- An agriculture expert said a rice shortage looms due to an expected drought to be caused by the El Nino phenomenon. (PHILIPPINE STAR)

- The Commission on Elections said government officials planning to run for the presidential elections next year should be aware that they face disqualification with premature campaigning. (MANILA BULLETIN)

- President Fidel Ramos assured there will be "no whitewash" in the investigation involving the death of an eight-year old girl who was in a car passing in front a suspected drug lord's house being raided by the police. (MANILA STANDARD)

- The Philippine National Police (PNP) said the team that raided a suspected drug lord house that resulted in the death of a girl violated standard rules of engagement as they did not wear proper nameplates, lacked uniforms and checkpoints. (MALAYA)
- National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) lawyers doubted that a suspected drug lord who recently surrendered to the police can become a state witness. (TODAY)

- A police superintendent asked to be transferred to a new post saying he was being pressured by politicians whose names he unearthed while trying to build a case against a suspected drug dealer who recently surrendered. (MANILA CHRONICLE)

- Seven police officers detailed at the office of a senator are facing dismissal for associating with an alleged "godfather" of local drug lords, the Philippine National Police director-general said. (INQUIRER)
- The central bank's Monetary Board has approved a three-month suspension of non-deliverable forward sales of foreign exchange. (ALL NEWSPAPERS)

- The Central Bank said it intends to invest the proceeds of the country's $715 million loan from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in interest-earning dollar instruments to recover its cost of using the funds. (BUSINESSWORLD)

- The country's gross international reserves is expected to improve by about 7.34 percent to $10.45 billion from $9.7 billion with the disbursement of the financing facility from the IMF. (ALL NEWSPAPERS)
